node.text:
We had the incredible honor of speaking with the new Secretary of Education Dr. Miguel Cardona (@seccardona) about the Administration’s vision for kids and families, especially as it relates to equity. We discuss the American Families Plan and how it will invest in and support access to child-care, preschool, higher education and more.

We talk about the critical role HBCUs play in our country and why the @whitehouse is investing $39 billion into subsidizing tuition for students who attend them, the importance of investing into a more diverse teacher pipeline, and why access to free high-quality preschool and free community college matters.

Dr. Cardona is a father and lifelong educator with over 2 decades of experience as a public school educator. We hope you enjoy this conversation and stay tuned in to the work he'll be doing as Secretary of Education.

Please check out the link in our bio or Stories to learn more.

#TeachersOfInstagram #HBCU #Education

node.title: Special conversation with Secretary of Education Dr. Miguel Cardona

node.text:
Cleo Wade's debut and NYTimes best-selling picture book, What The Road Said, is not only a must-read, it is a comforting, wisdom-filled, and uplifting guide for kids to look to as they navigate their own journeys in life. We know it’s one kids will look to and revisit often for reassurance and guidance. It’s so valuable for all ages and stages of life and one that readers will be lifted up by through its encouraging and nurturing words. Reading this book feels like sitting down with a trusted and loving friend. 

We hope you enjoy this conversation about the book with @jennifer.garner as part of our @onceuponafarm Storyteller series. We also have 10 signed copies of What The Road Said to giveaway—please comment below if we can send you one.

node.text:
Talks to us about @virulenthate's newest report analyzing anti-Asian racism in 2020. The Virulent Hate Project identifies, analyzes, and maps incidents of anti-Asian harassment, violence, discrimination, and stigmatization, and researches trends in anti-Asian racism and Asian American activism. 

Their new report released this week examined over 4,337 pieces of news media on anti-Asian racism and found that of the incidents where the race of the perpetrator is known, they are predominantly male and disproportionately white. This is significant because the videos being centered and receiving mass circulation in the media and on social media have been creating a misconception that the majority of perpetrators are Black.

Dr. Borja speaks with us about the key findings of the new report, the ongoing trope of Black/Asian conflict and why it's important for us to think critically about how we may be reproducing that harmful narrative, how Black and Asian communities have been working in solidarity in response to anti-Asian racism, and how we can continue to show solidarity in the future and support our communities.

Special thanks to Dr. Borja for her time and for sharing her work and expertise with us! Please be sure to stay tuned for her next report on Asian American activism.

For more information, visit virulenthate.org. Dr. Borja is on IG and Twitter at @melissamayborja

node.title: Dr. Melissa May Borja, lead of the Virulent Hate Project

node.text:
Repost from @wongfupro
•
If you didn't know, May is Asian Pacific American Heritage Month. Although we're bringing attention to this in May, we hope the message will continue to resonate + be heard moving forward. Let’s keep on educating, speaking out, and uplifting. #StopAsianHate #APAHM

For more verified donation pages and organization fundraisers visit:
https://www.gofundme.com/c/act/stop-aapi-hate

node.title: PSA from our Asian Creator Community by @wongfupro via @goldhouseco

node.text:
We partnered with @harryshumjr and @wongfupro to bring you a storytime playlist celebrating AAPI voices and experiences. Today, we are so excited to share the first read-aloud video with you!

Harry will be reading Grandpa Grumps by @katrinamoore1011 and @xindiyanart, published by @littlebeebooks. Please check it out now on the YouTube Kids app and our YouTube channel (linked in our Stories). 

We hope you love it and share it with your kids and students. Please stay tuned for new read-alouds each week this month featuring @padmalakshmi, @mingna_wen and Randall Park!

#AAPIStorytime #ReadAloud #AsianAmerican #AAPI #StopAsianHate

node.title: AAPI Storytime featuring Harry Shum Jr.

node.text: I Am Smart, I Am Blessed, I Can Do ANYTHING! In this special episode of #Storytellers, @jennifer.garner chats with @ayaandiop, the kid whose positive energy landed him a viral video of his walk to school, and inspired his mom, @alissa360style, and aunt, @AMomDotCom to write @ImSmartImBlessedICanDoAnything - a children's book that shows the importance of affirmations at any age. As @jennifer.garner reminds us, “All of us can benefit from taking a look at how we talk to ourselves.”

node.text:
From @tiffanyhaddish:
•
I was Working today for @kidssaythedarndestthings
Airing very soon on @cbstv . The Producers decided to tell me I WON a Grammy while I was interviewing these two young ladies Lauren and Ava, that want to someday be president of the United States of America. I was flooded with a such a since of accomplishment and relief. I kinda didn’t know what to say. I just wanted to cry but I knew it would have confused the babies. So I decided to use that moment to teach and share my feelings. Thank you @recordingacademy  for the honor. Thank you to everyone that made #blackmitzvah happen @pushitproductions @pagehurwitz #wandasykes #netflix #JackieKnobbe #Dionnewynn #yvettesheldon #LawRoach #jerrodcarmichael #lilrelhowery #chrisspencer #shereadyproductions #SHEREADY

node.text: It is our absolute privilege to host @SecondGentleman Douglas Emhoff in this very special story time. In celebration of Read Across America Day and Women's History Month, Mr. Emhoff is reading the book I Dissent: Ruth Bader Ginsburg Makes Her Mark by Debbie Levy and Elizabeth Baddeley. We hope you love it as much as we do! @simonkids

node.title: National Read Across America Day with Douglas Emhoff

node.text:
We are so excited to feature @meena in conversation with @jennifer.garner for this month’s @onceuponafarm Storytellers! 

Meena’s newest book, Ambitious Girl, is out tomorrow! It is an affirmation to young girls that they can do and be anything. It’s message of owning and living your purpose, not letting anyone tell you who you are, and being unapologetic about taking up space (in a world that too often tells Black girls and girls of color that they are “too loud” “too much”, and “too confident”) is deeply needed and important. 

In addition to Ambitious Girl, Meena also talks about her first book, Kamala and Maya’s Big Idea, and its message that no matter how small, each of us can make an impact. 

Please be sure to check out Meena’s movement and the incredible work she does in support of social and racial justice organizations with @phenomenal. Visit our Stories for the Once Upon A Farm blog post with links to Meena’s website and books.

We are so excited to host Jingle Jangle producer, @lynsissontalbert, as she reads aloud her picture book, The Square Root of Possible, based on the beautiful new @netflix holiday film. The book is co-authored by Jingle Jangle writer/director, @davidetalbert. 

Be sure to also check out the middle-grade book they co-wrote, called Jingle Jangle: The Invention of Jeronicus Jangle, for ages 8-12. 

Special thanks to Lyn and @penguinkids for this wonderful storytime. We appreciate you tuning in and wish you happy holidays!

node.text:
The Conscious Kid is honored to be partnered with @pjlibrary to share Jewish voices and stories. Providing early education about Jewish contributions, history and culture is an essential component of affirming Jewish identity and countering antisemitism. 

In celebration of Rosh Hashanah, PJ Library has curated a list of their favorite children’s books about the Jewish New Year. Rosh Hashanah is the first of the two fall High Holidays. The other is Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement. 

Rosh Hashanah is often referred to as the birthday of the world. It’s a time to reflect, sing, pray, gather with loved ones and, of course, eat delicious apple treats and round challah. This year it will begin in the evening on Monday, September 6, 2021 and end in the evening on Wednesday, September 8, 2021.

The books in the following list make a wonderful introduction to the High Holidays. The last two titles aren’t about the Jewish holidays per se, but they’re both great stories to help young children learn the value of saying “I’m sorry” and making amends. This full list, along with book descriptions and suggested age ranges, is available under the Book List section of our website. 

For additional titles, please see the PJ Library free digital guide for families, available at pjlibrary.org/rosh-hashanah.

🎨: @sophia_vincent_guy

node.text:
“When I was 12, after I hit puberty, I started wearing hijab every day. Before then, my mother would have me wear hijab on special occasions and to school on the days when I didn’t have gym. Having my friends, classmates, and teachers see me wearing hijab a few times a week made the transition to wearing it everyday easier. Still, and even though my parents did a great job preparing me spiritually and physically for covering my hair, I faced bullying from classmates because of the way I showed my faith. I clearly remember one boy in middle school asking me why I was wearing “that tablecloth on my head.” It was at that time, in middle school, that I realized my faith had the power to change how people treated me and that I may be “othered”—all because of my hijab. You wouldn’t think that a simple head-scarf could cause such commotion, but throughout my childhood, adolescence, and adulthood, it has. I wanted to tell this story so that children who look like me could see themselves in a picture book—a story of family, love, and faith. So that they can see two sisters taking pride in hijab, & see that the parts of ourselves that might make us appear “different” are worth celebrating. So that children of color, Muslims, and those who are both (like me) know they aren’t alone & that there are many out there who share our experience. Finally, I want to say it loud and proud. My hijab is part of me—it’s a testament to my faith and love of Allah. It’s a tradition I share enthusiastically with my mother & sisters. My hijab is beautiful. To the young girls out there reading this story who are hijabis: So is yours.”
—Author and Olympic Gold Medalist Ibtihaj Muhammad
✨
With her new backpack and light-up shoes, Faizah knows the first day of school is going to be special. It's the start of a brand new year & her older sister Asiya's first day of hijab. But not everyone sees hijab as beautiful, and in the face of hurtful, confusing words, Faizah will find new ways to be strong.

This beautiful, heart-warming book is an essential addition to classroom libraries and to kick off the school year. Written by @ibtihajmuhammad @skalibooks, illustrated by @metahatem. Ages 4-8.

node.text:
"I wrote [Your Name is A Song] in hopes of changing the conversation about whose names are worthy of being pronounced correctly and respected. It's sad that there are adults today who think it's fine to diminish the names of others. I continue to say that when we accept the diminishing of the things that make up a person's identity, we also open the door to diminishing that person's humanity. Let's not accept it. Let's push back and make them say (or sing) our names." — @authorjamilah 

Your Name Is A Song addresses the common microaggression of people mispronouncing names.

This book is an important counter-narrative that encourages kids to be proud of their names, which of course are not just names, but extensions of our families, histories, and identities. It also pushes back against ideas and norms that kids need to change anything about themselves to fit in or exist in a certain way. 

It engages this issue from the perspective of a child on the first day of school whose own name is being mispronounced. She doesn't want to go back to school because no one, not even her teacher, can say her name correctly. 

“She tried. It got stuck in her mouth.”

In response, the girl's mother teaches her about the musicality of African, Asian, Black American, Latinx, and Middle Eastern names on their lyrical walk home through the city. 

Empowered by this newfound understanding, the young girl is ready to return the next day to share her knowledge with her class. Your Name is a Song is a celebration to remind all of us about the beauty, history, and magic behind names. 

It’s a perfect book to kick off the school year and underscore the importance of honoring each other’s names and identities, and not being afraid to be and show up as ourselves.

Written by @authorjamilah, illustrated by @lupencita. Ages 4-8.

node.text:
Stepping into a new classroom at the start of the school year can be hard, full of uncertainty, and scary, especially if you feel “different” from your peers. 

There may be many reasons to feel different. Maybe it's how you look or talk, or where you're from or what you eat. It's not easy to take those first steps into a place where nobody really knows you yet, but somehow you do it. 

National Book Award winner @jacqueline_woodson and two-time Pura Belpré Illustrator Award winner @rafael_l61 teamed up to create this heartening book about finding courage to connect, even when you feel scared and alone. 

It reminds us that we all feel like outsiders sometimes—and how brave it is that we go forth anyway. And that sometimes, when we reach out and begin to share our stories, others will be happy to meet us halfway. 

The Day You Begin encourages us to be ourselves, find the beauty in who we are, and share it with the world. 

This book is also available in Spanish, as El Día En Que Descubres Quién Eres! Ages 4-8.

node.text:
It’s back to school time so we are going to be sharing some of our favorite books for supporting inclusive classrooms that welcome students of all identities and foster a sense of belonging. First up is All Are Welcome by Alexandra Penfold and @suzannekaufman.

All Are Welcome lets young children know that no matter what, they have a place, they have a space, they are welcome in their school.

In our classroom safe and sound. Fears are lost and hope is found. 

Follow a group of children through a day in their school, where everyone is welcomed with open arms no matter their race, religion or background. A school where students grow and learn from each other's traditions and the whole community gathers to celebrate the Lunar New Year. A school where diversity and inclusion is celebrated and all young children are loved and appreciated. “You have a place here. / You have a space here. / You are welcome here.”

The book jacket unfolds into a poster (pictured in the last image). 

Have you read this one?

Ages 3-8.

node.text:
We are honored to co-host a 5 part educator PD series in partnership with Schooltalking and @usvshate. The series will focus on teaching against hate, bias and injustice through accurate and inclusive teaching and feature some key organizations supporting educators right now, including @facinghistory, @nationalwritingproject, @welcoming_schools, Schooltalking and the Center for Antiracist Education. 

The first event featuring @facinghistory kicks off this Wednesday, August 25 at 4 pm PT/7 pm ET. Facing History And Ourselves uses lessons of history to challenge teachers and their students to stand up to bigotry and hate. Their resources address racism, antisemitism, and prejudice at pivotal moments in history, and they help students connect choices made in the past to those they will confront in their own lives. They will be sharing their “Back to School” Toolkit and experienced educators will be sharing approaches to open, supportive and reflective classrooms.

All of the events are free and will take place on Zoom. Register at: supportingallofus.eventbrite.com. 

**Please note: Educators and their schools have been getting targeted for teaching antiracism and accurate history. For safety purposes, please feel free to use a different name or pseudonym on Zoom to protect your identity and the schools and/or organizations you work at. You are also welcome to have your camera turned off.**

Swipe to see more information on each event and the incredible participating organizations. We look forward to connecting with you on Wednesday and each week of the series!

node.text:
We are equally excited and honored to host the cover reveal for Stella Keeps the Sun Up, a new joy-filled adventure by Clothilde Ewing from the beloved @denenemillnerbooks imprint! 

In this incandescently fun, hijinks-filled picture book, a young girl schemes to keep the sun up in the sky so she never has to go to bed.

If Stella had her way, she would stop sleeping on her sixth birthday. Because sleep is boring. And there are so many better things you could be doing. And Stella is tired of being tired. So she comes up with a plan. People only have to go to bed when it gets dark, and it only gets dark because the sun goes down. If she can keep the sun in the sky, she and her best friend, Roger, can stay up for a hundred years!

They enact their magnificent, wonderful, genius plan, offering the sun a cup of coffee, shining a light at it so it will shine back, and jumping on a trampoline to reach the sun and push it higher. But before long, Stella begins to wonder…are there downsides to keeping the sun up forever?

“STELLA is a character—funny, full of personality and spirited. I created her that way because children who look like her—my children and so many others—deserve to see that kind of iconic character on a series of adventures, on the order of, say, an Eloise or a Fancy Nancy, in the same skin they're in. It is my deepest desire, too, that children who don't resemble STELLA be inspired by her and Roger and each of their stories because the characters are relatable, fun and love a great adventure. I'm thrilled to introduce them to the world!” —Author Clothilde Ewing

Stella Keeps the Sun Up will be released March 8, 2022. Click the link in our bio to preorder and stay tuned for updates at @stellalovesroger. 

@simonkids @lynngainesart @mybrownbaby

node.text:
Black boy joy is…
 
Picking out a fresh first-day-of-school outfit.
Saving the universe in an epic intergalactic race.
Finding your voice—and your rhymes—during tough times.
Flying on your skateboard like nobody’s watching.

And so much more.

Yet, the narratives about Black males that dominate news and media tend to be rooted in deficits, stereotypes, and pain. We don’t often get to see nuance, diverse expressions of Blackness or the everyday dreams and experiences of Black boys. 

BLACK BOY JOY celebrates the joys of Black boyhood with stories from seventeen bestselling, critically acclaimed Black male and non-binary authors—including @jasonreynolds83 (the Track series), @jerrycraft (New Kid), and @mbalia1 (the Tristan Strong series).

Additional contributors include: B. B. Alston, Dean Atta, P. Djèlí Clark, Jay Coles, Lamar Giles, Don P. Hooper, George M. Johnson, Varian Johnson, Suyi Davies Okungbowa, Tochi Onyebuchi, Julian Randall, Justin Reynolds, DaVaun Sanders, and Julian Winters. 

This new must-read middle grade collection was released today and is available now. Ages 8-12. 

Cover art by @kadirnelson.

node.text:
A picture book biography of the GOAT, Simone Biles. 

Before she was a record-breaking gymnast competing on the world stage, Simone Biles spent time in foster care as a young child. When she was six years old, Simone's family took shape in a different way. Her grandparents Ron and Nellie Biles adopted Simone and her sister Adria. Ron and Nellie became their parents. Simone was also introduced to gymnastics that same year, launching a lifelong passion fueled by remarkable talent, sacrifice, and the undying support of her family.

From her athletic early childhood to the height of her success as an Olympic champion, Flying High is the story of the world's greatest gymnast from author Michelle Meadows and illustrator @artsyebby. Ages 4-8.

node.text:
Do you know the story of the first Asian American to win an Olympic gold medal for the United States?

On a summer day in California in 1932, twelve-year-old Sammy Lee watched enviously as divers catapulted into the public swimming pool. Sammy desperately wanted to try diving himself, but the Korean American boy — like any person of color — was only allowed to use the pool one day a week, on Wednesdays, after which the pool was completely drained and refilled. 

This discrimination did not weaken Sammy's newfound passion for diving, and soon he began a struggle between his dream of becoming an Olympic champion and his father's wish for him to become a doctor. Over sixteen years Sammy faced numerous challenges, but he overcame and fulfilled both his dream and his father's. In 1948, Dr. Sammy Lee dove into Olympic history. A matter of seconds after his final platform dive, the scores appeared and Sammy Lee became the first Asian American to win an Olympic gold medal for the United States.

Lee was also the first person of color to win a national diving title and was inducted into the International Swimming Hall of Fame in 1968 and U.S. Olympic Hall of Fame in 1990.

His story of determination and triumph sets an extraordinary example for anyone striving to fulfill a dream. Written by @paulayoo, illustrated by Dom Lee. Ages 6-10. @leeandlow

May be an image of text that says 'For Immediate Release The Conscious Kid Responds to False Claims by Project Veritas The organization targeted this week in smear campaign, The Conscious Kid, issued today their response to an edited and secretly recorded video which claims to "blow the whistle" on publicly available research in attempts to falsely represent the organization's work. The group behind the smear campaign, Project Veritas, is known for its connections to hate groups that promote racial violence has long history of failed sting operations designed spread false or misleading information to discredit individuals and organizations that work to address systemic racism and inequity.'.

node.text:
“The Conscious Kid supports organizations, families, and educators in taking action to disrupt racism and racial bias, extensively documented by research to start in early childhood. That includes partnering with entities big and small who share a vision of a world where every child has the opportunity to grow up experiencing inclusion, respect, and belonging. We are proud to partner with families, educators, and organizations committed to drive meaningful change toward those goals

We welcome this moment as an opportunity to deepen existing conversations around countering bias and disrupting racism early. Numerous scientific studies show that development of racial identity and racial bias in kids of all races begins early, persists through adulthood, and shapes the way we see and interact with the world. 

Research has shown that young children notice and think about race. While adults often worry that talking about race will encourage racial bias in children, data proves the opposite is true. 

We are never "too young" to talk about race and racial differences and silence about race reinforces racism and racial bias. It’s important to note that implicit biases remain stable unless proactive action is taken to reduce them and we know that teachers and families can play a powerful role in helping children of all ages develop positive attitudes about race and diversity, and skills that will move us closer towards a more just future. 

We understand the agenda of groups behind videos like this – to intimidate and silence people with false accusations that work to divide and keep people unaware about the importance of anti-racism work. Unfortunately, these tactics will be effective for some and that empirical research is seen as a “view” or an opinion rather than as factual. However, we remain committed to being a research-based organization and continue our work for justice, equity, and inclusion.

We refuse to be distracted from our vision for change.”
